hints.content: Start by understanding the numeric value of each character. The character 'a' has a value of 1, 'b' has 2, and so on up to 'z' which has a value of 26.
Remember that the total numeric value of the string must equal k. This means that the sum of the values of the characters you choose must equal k.
Consider the constraints: the length of the string is n, and the minimum possible value of k is n (if all characters are 'a'). This means k must be between n and 26 * n.
To create the lexicographically smallest string, start filling the string from the leftmost character to the right. This means using the smallest possible characters first.
If you fill the string with 'a's initially, you can then adjust the last characters to reach the desired numeric value k. Calculate how much more you need to reach k after filling with 'a's.
Calculate the initial sum if you fill the string with 'a's: it will be n (since each 'a' contributes 1). Determine how much more you need to add to reach k: this is k - n.

Distributing the remaining value across the characters can be done by increasing characters from 'a' to higher values. Start from the end of the string and work backwards to maintain lexicographical order.
When adjusting characters, ensure that you do not exceed the value of 26 for any character. If you need to add more than 25 to a character, you will need to adjust multiple characters.
Consider edge cases, such as when n = 1 or k = n. In these cases, the string will either be a single character or all 'a's, depending on k.

Finally, construct the string by iterating from the last character to the first, adjusting each character based on the remaining value needed to reach k, while ensuring you maintain the smallest lexicographical order.

questionNotes: The string must be exactly length n and have a numeric value of k.
Lexicographical order means the string should be the smallest possible in dictionary order.
Characters are indexed from 1 to 26 corresponding to 'a' to 'z'.
